results.title: Donald's better self
results.creator_credit: Jack King, Walt Disney and Walt Disney Productions
results.brief_description: Donald Duck has two sides to his character. On the one hand, his good self strives to do the right thing, but his bad self usually wins. Donald sleeps late in the morning, and it takes his better self to make him dress and start off the school. On the way to school his bad self entices him to play truant.

results.title: Donald in Mathmagic land
results.creator_credit: Hamilton Luske, Walt Disney and Walt Disney Productions
results.brief_description: Donald Duck participates in a remarkable adventure and learns that music, architecture, art and science are all based on mathematical principles. Tracing the history and development of these principles, we find the Arabs responsible for our present numbers and algebra; Egypt the source of geometric theories, the pyramids remaining as a monument to their knowledge of the triangle; and to the Greeks Pythagoras we owe our musical scale.

results.title: Donald and the wheel
results.creator_credit: Hamilton Luske and Walt Disney Productions
results.brief_description: Donald Duck accidently invents the wheel. Later Egyptians, Greek, Romans and others improve on it. Through songs and commentary the possible history of the wheel is traced. Donald, however, is not very impressed, particularly the aspect of the chaos of modern traffic.

results.title: Don Pasquale
results.brief_description: Donizetti’s comic opera, sung in Italian and narrated in English. Performed by the members of the Scala of Milano at the Opera House of Rome.

results.title: The Dolmetsch story. Part 1. Recorders
results.creator_credit: Educational Foundation for Visual Aids and Fanelodge Productions
results.brief_description: Part one of a series of three films. Carl Dometsch, probably the greatest recorder player of all time, is head of the Dolmetsch workshops in Haslemere where many ancient musical instruments have been reconstructed and copied. Dr Dolemetsch describes the history of the recorder and demonstrates the musical qualities of each member of the recorder family. Suitable for secondary school level.

results.title: Dolls of many lands
results.brief_description: Shows dolls exhibited at an international fair and now permanently housed in a famous collection in Italy. The dolls are dressed in folk costumes and are shown in settings which closely resemble some characteristic natural background of the doll’s native land. Suitable for primary school level.

results.title: Dolls (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: G.A. Howe, MacMillan Film Productions and Pre-School Education Project
results.brief_description: Indicates how realistic play with dolls helps children learn about human relationships and come to terms with babies in their own families. The class watches while a child’s mother washes and dresses her baby and the children copy her with their dolls.

results.title: Dollars or decay
results.creator_credit: Department of Health Services and Tasmanian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Illustrates the consequences that a poor or bad diet has on teeth. Attention is especially drawn to food served in school tuckshops. Section on good nutrition habits and how to give children low cost healthy food that they like.

results.title: Dog's heaven
results.creator_credit: H Tyrlova and Short Film Studio
results.brief_description: Using wool fibre, a flexible material for animation, this film tells the story of a little black dog, slightly disappointed in his master, who has a brief sojourn in Dog’s Heaven. Instrumentation comes from three harpists, trumpeters, double bassists and a chorus.

results.title: The Dogfish as a vertebrate
results.brief_description: Deals with the Dogfish as a typical vertebrate, illustrating its anatomy in detail. Comparisons with four other types are given; i.e., with newt, lizard, bird and rabbit. Fishes, amphibians, reptiles, birds and mammals included in vertebrates; basic plan demonstrated by Dogfish. Alimentary canal has mouth, oesophagus, stomach, intestinal colonic regions; liver and pancreas; also central nervous system, sense organs. Detail from Dogfish; comparisons in the other four types (frog, lizard, bird and rabbit). Skeleton - axial and appendicular - common to all. Respiratory system involves large surfaces for oxygenation of blood - gills, lungs. Ventral position of heart; plans of blood systems. Gills as embryonic vestiges. Urinogenital systems association. Sexual reproduction and separate sexes common to vertebrates; detail for Dogfish (internal fertilization), Frog (external fertilization).
